title: Registering with Smartraveller website essential first stop for ease in case of an emergency | Travel | Travel News and Holiday Deals |
text:
We have an agreement that I check in when I’m away just so he knows where I am and, should the worst happen, be able to track me down.
But what options do travellers sans a vigilant father have for staying on the radar when roaming in remote – and not so remote – corners of the planet?
The first stop is Smartraveller, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) service that lets those about to pack their passport monitor the safety status of spots they plan to see and register plans so they can be located in the event of a natural or man-made emergency.
REGISTER YOUR PLANS
“All Australians, those travelling for the first time as well as seasoned travellers, should register on Smartraveller,’’ DFAT’s assistant secretary for consular services Angus Mackenzie says.
“Crises can occur anywhere and at any time, and Australians planning travel to remote locations where the security environment is more challenging are particularly advised to register their plans.
“The information is used by DFAT to deliver consular services when a crisis hits – be it an earthquake, flood, or major civil unrest – and we attempt to contact people we know to be in the region using the details they’ve provided on their registration.
“We use Smartraveller information whenever there’s a crisis or an Australian goes missing overseas, it was most recently used following the cyclone in Vanuatu and earthquake in Nepal, and we’re in the final stages of a major revamp that will make it even easier to use.’’
HELP YOURSELF
“Smartraveller provides credible, up-to-date information for most locations Australians travel to, and travellers can subscribe to advice for countries they’re visiting and receive updates by email as conditions change,’’ Angus says.
“We expect Australians to use the resources available to them before turning to the government for assistance – research your destination, including reading and subscribing to Smartraveller, and take out appropriate insurance – (and) well-prepared travellers can solve most problems themselves. Emergency consular assistance is available 24 hours by calling our Consular Emergency Centre in Canberra and the contact details for high commissions and consulates are available online ( dfat.gov.au/missions ) or in local phone directories, hotels, tourist offices and police stations.’’
STAY IN TOUCH
Though DFAT is there to help should something go dramatically wrong, it’s still a good idea to communicate with home so family and friends have a vague idea where you are, what you’re doing and where you’re going next.
I check in twice a day when I’m away and while it’s often a text message from my mobile – as a Telstra customer it generally costs me 75¢ to SMS a few words – Wi-Fi offered free in trains, airports, cafes and hotels means it costs nothing to send an email, Instagram post or Facebook update.
And I always leave a copy of my itinerary at home, with hotels listed when reservations are made in advance, so a quick check can be made when trouble spots feature on the evening news bulletins.
